blocks.name: wl-mps
blocks.content: Replacing a nested consequent. A sort of modus ponens in antecedent position. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 20-Sep-2013.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: wl-syls1
blocks.content: Replacing a nested consequent. A sort of syllogism in antecedent position. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 20-Sep-2013.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: wl-syls2
blocks.content: Replacing a nested antecedent. A sort of syllogism in antecedent position. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 20-Sep-2013.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: wl-embant
blocks.content: A true wff can always be added as a nested antecedent to an antecedent. Note: this theorem is intuitionistically valid. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 4-Oct-2013.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: wl-orel12
blocks.content: In a conjunctive normal form a pair of nodes like ` ( ph \/ ps ) /\ ( -. ph \/ ch ) ` eliminates the need of a node ` ( ps \/ ch ) ` . This theorem allows simplifications in that respect. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 20-Jun-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-orel12(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wi(wa(wo(w0, w1), wo(wn(w0), w2)), wo(w1, w2))
} = {
  mpi(wa(wo(w0, w1), wo(wn(w0), w2)), wo(w1, w2), wo(wn(w0), w0))
  pm2.1(w0)
  jaao(wo(w0, w1), wo(wn(w0), w2), wn(w0), w0, wo(w1, w2))
  syl6com(wo(w0, w1), wn(w0), wo(w1, w2), w1)
  orel1(w0, w1)
  orc(w1, w2)
  syl6com(wo(wn(w0), w2), w0, wo(w1, w2), w2)
  syl(w0, wi(wo(wn(w0), w2), w2), wn(wn(w0)))
  notnot(w0)
  orel1(wn(w0), w2)
  olc(w2, w1)
}

blocks.name: wl-cases2-dnf
blocks.content: A particular instance of ~ orddi and ~ anddi converting between disjunctive and conjunctive normal forms, when both ` ph ` and ` -. ph ` appear. This theorem in fact rephrases ~ cases2 , and is related to ~ consensus . I restate it here in DNF and CNF. The proof deliberately does not use ~ df-ifp and ~ dfifp4 , by which it can be shortened. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 21-Jun-2020.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-cases2-dnf(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wb(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w0, w2)))
} = {
  3bitr2i(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w0, w2)), wa(wa(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1)), wo(w2, w1)), wa(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1)))
  3bitr4ri(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wa(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1)), wo(w2, w1)), wa(wo(w0, w2), wa(wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w2, w1))), wa(wa(wo(w0, wn(w0)), wo(w0, w2)), wa(wo(w1, wn(w0)), wo(w1, w2))))
  anbi12i(wo(w0, w2), wa(wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w2, w1)), wa(wo(w0, wn(w0)), wo(w0, w2)), wa(wo(w1, wn(w0)), wo(w1, w2)))
  biantrur(wo(w0, w2), wo(w0, wn(w0)))
  exmid(w0)
  anbi12i(wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w2, w1), wo(w1, wn(w0)), wo(w1, w2))
  orcom(wn(w0), w1)
  orcom(w2, w1)
  anass(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1), wo(w2, w1))
  orddi(w0, w1, wn(w0), w2)
  pm4.71i(wa(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1)), wo(w2, w1))
  wl-orel12(w0, w2, w1)
  ancom(wo(w0, w2), wo(wn(w0), w1))
}

blocks.name: wl-cbvmotv
blocks.content: Change bound variable. Uses only Tarski's FOL axiom schemes. Part of Lemma 7 of [KalishMontague] p. 86. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Mar-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-cbvmotv(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  |- wi(wmo(s0, wtru), wmo(s1, wtru))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
} = {
  3imtr4i(wmo(s0, wtru), wmo(s1, wtru), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))), wex(hs0, wal(s1, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0))))))
  eximi(hs0, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s1, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)))))
  cbvalivw(s0, s1, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0))))
  imim2d(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)), wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)))
  ax7v2(s0, s1, hs0)
  df-mo(s0, hs0, wtru)
  df-mo(s1, hs0, wtru)
  diff.wi.s(s0, wtru, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)))
  diff.wtru.s(s0)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, cv(s1), cv(hs0))
  diff.cv.s(s0, s1)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diff.wi.s(s1, wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, cv(s0), cv(hs0))
  diff.cv.s(s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(wtru)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-cbvmotv(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  ⊢ (∃*(s0, T)→ ∃*(s1, T))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
} = {
  3imtr4i(∃*(s0, T), ∃*(s1, T), ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = hs0))), ∃(hs0, ∀(s1,(T → s1 = hs0))))
  eximi(hs0, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = hs0)), ∀(s1,(T → s1 = hs0)))
  cbvalivw(s0, s1, (T → s0 = hs0), (T → s1 = hs0))
  imim2d(s0 = s1, wtru, s0 = hs0, s1 = hs0)
  ax7v2(s0, s1, hs0)
  df-mo(s0, hs0, wtru)
  df-mo(s1, hs0, wtru)
  diff.wi.s(s0, wtru, s1 = hs0)
  diff.wtru.s(s0)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, s1, hs0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, s1)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diff.wi.s(s1, wtru, s0 = hs0)
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, s0, hs0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(wtru)
}

blocks.name: wl-moteq
blocks.content: Change bound variable. Uses only Tarski's FOL axiom schemes. Part of Lemma 7 of [KalishMontague] p. 86. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Mar-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-moteq(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2) {
  |- wi(wmo(s0, wtru), wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))
} = {
  sylbi(wmo(s0, wtru), wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))))
  df-mo(s0, hs0, wtru)
  exlimiv(hs0, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))
  syl(wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), wi(wtru, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))))
  stdpc5v(s0, wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))
  ja(wtru, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))
  pm2.24i(wtru, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))
  tru()
  aeveq(s0, hs0, s1, s2)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(wtru)
  diff.hs0.w(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))
  diff.wtru.s(s0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-moteq(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2) {
  ⊢ (∃*(s0, T)→ s1 = s2)
} = {
  sylbi(∃*(s0, T), s1 = s2, ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = hs0))))
  df-mo(s0, hs0, wtru)
  exlimiv(hs0, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = hs0)), s1 = s2)
  syl(∀(s0,(T → s0 = hs0)), s1 = s2, (T → ∀(s0, s0 = hs0)))
  stdpc5v(s0, wtru, s0 = hs0)
  ja(wtru, ∀(s0, s0 = hs0), s1 = s2)
  pm2.24i(wtru, s1 = s2)
  tru()
  aeveq(s0, hs0, s1, s2)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(wtru)
  diff.hs0.w(s1 = s2)
  diff.wtru.s(s0)
}

blocks.name: wl-motae
blocks.content: Change bound variable. Uses only Tarski's FOL axiom schemes. Part of Lemma 7 of [KalishMontague] p. 86. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Mar-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-motae(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wi(wmo(s0, wtru), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s3))))
} = {
  syl(wmo(s0, wtru), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s3))), wmo(hs0, wtru))
  wl-cbvmotv(s0, hs0)
  alrimiv(s1, wmo(hs0, wtru), wceq(cv(s2), cv(s3)))
  wl-moteq(hs0, s2, s3)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.wmo.s(s1, hs0, wtru)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-motae(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ⊢ (∃*(s0, T)→ ∀(s1, s2 = s3))
} = {
  syl(∃*(s0, T), ∀(s1, s2 = s3), ∃*(hs0, T))
  wl-cbvmotv(s0, hs0)
  alrimiv(s1, ∃*(hs0, T), s2 = s3)
  wl-moteq(hs0, s2, s3)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.wmo.s(s1, hs0, wtru)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: wl-moae
blocks.content: Two ways to express "at most one thing exists" or, in this context equivalently, "exactly one thing exists" . The equivalence results from the presence of ~ ax-6 in the proof, that ensures "at least one thing exists". For other equivalences see ~ wl-euae and ~ exists1 . Gerard Lang pointed out, that ` E. y A. x x = y ` with disjoint ` x ` and ` y ` ( ~ df-mo , ~ trut ) also means "exactly one thing exists" . (Contributed by NM, 5-Apr-2004.) State the theorem using truth constant ` T. ` . (Revised by BJ, 7-Oct-2022.) Reduce axiom dependencies, and use ` E* ` . (Revised by Wolf Lammen, 7-Mar-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-moae(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  |- wb(wmo(s0, wtru), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
} = {
  impbii(wmo(s0, wtru), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  wl-motae(s0, s0, s0, s1)
  sylibr(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wmo(s0, wtru), wex(s1, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))))
  syl(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wex(s1, wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wex(s1, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  19.8w(s1, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  hbaev(s0, s1, s1)
  eximi(s1, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  alimi(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wtru, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  ax-1(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wtru)
  df-mo(s0, s1, wtru)
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-moae(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  ⊢ (∃*(s0, T)↔ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
} = {
  impbii(∃*(s0, T), ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  wl-motae(s0, s0, s0, s1)
  sylibr(∀(s0, s0 = s1), ∃*(s0, T), ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = s1))))
  syl(∀(s0, s0 = s1), ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(T → s0 = s1))), ∃(s1, ∀(s0, s0 = s1)))
  19.8w(s1, ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  hbaev(s0, s1, s1)
  eximi(s1, ∀(s0, s0 = s1), ∀(s0,(T → s0 = s1)))
  alimi(s0, s0 = s1, (T → s0 = s1))
  ax-1(s0 = s1, wtru)
  df-mo(s0, s1, wtru)
  diff.wtru.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: wl-euae
blocks.content: Two ways to express "exactly one thing exists" . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Mar-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-nax6im
blocks.content: The following series of theorems are centered around the empty domain, where no set exists. As a consequence, a set variable like ` x ` has no instance to assign to. An expression like ` x = y ` is not really meaningful then. What does it evaluate to, true or false? In fact, the grammar extension ~ weq requires us to formally assign a boolean value to an equation, say always false, unless you want to give up on ~ exmid , for example. Whatever it is, we start out with the contraposition of ~ ax-6 , that guarantees the existence of at least one set. Our hypothesis here expresses tentatively it might not hold. We can simplify the antecedent then, to the point where we do not need equation any more. This suggests what a decent characterization of the empty domain could be. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 12-Mar-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-nax6al
blocks.content: In an empty domain the for-all operator always holds, even when applied to a false expression. This theorem actually shows that ~ ax-5 is provable there. Also we cannot assume that ~ sp generally holds, except of course in the form of ~ sptruw . Without the support of an ~ sp like theorem it seems difficult, if not impossible, to arrive at a theorem allowing to change the bounded variable in the antecedent. Additional axioms need to be postulated to further strengthen this result. A consequence of this result is that ` E. x ph ` is not true for any ` ph ` . In particular, ` E* x ph ` does not hold either, a somewhat counterintuitive result. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 12-Mar-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-nax6nfr
blocks.content: All expressions are free of the variable used in the antecedent. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 12-Mar-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-naev
blocks.content: If some set variables can assume different values, then any two distinct set variables cannot always be the same. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 10-Aug-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-hbae1
blocks.content: This specialization of ~ hbae does not depend on ~ ax-11 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 8-Aug-2021.)

blocks.name: wl-naevhba1v
blocks.content: An instance of ~ hbn1w applied to equality. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 7-Apr-2021.)

blocks.name: wl-spae
blocks.content: Prove an instance of ~ sp from ~ ax-13 and Tarski's FOL only, without distinct variable conditions. The antecedent ` A. x x = y ` holds in a multi-object universe only if ` y ` is substituted for ` x ` , or vice versa, i.e. both variables are effectively the same. The converse ` -. A. x x = y ` indicates that both variables are distinct, and it so provides a simple translation of a distinct variable condition to a logical term. In case studies ` A. x x = y ` and ` -. A. x x = y ` can help eliminating distinct variable conditions. The antecedent ` A. x x = y ` is expressed in the theorem's name by the abbreviation ae standing for 'all equal'. Note that we cannot provide a logical predicate telling us directly whether a logical expression contains a particular variable, as such a construct would usually contradict ~ ax-12 . Note that this theorem is also provable from ~ ax-12 alone, so you can pick the axiom it is based on. Compare this result to ~ 19.3v and ~ spaev having distinct variable conditions, but a smaller footprint on axiom usage. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Apr-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-spae(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  |- wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
} = {
  exlimiiv(hs0, wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)))
  pm2.61dan(wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  a1d(wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  adantl(wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  aeveq(s0, hs0, s0, s1)
  con4d(wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  impcom(wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wi(wn(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))))
  com13(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wn(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  syl6(wn(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0))))
  ax13v(s0, s1, hs0)
  con3d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  al2imi(s0, wceq(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))
  equtrr(s1, hs0, s0)
  ax6evr(hs0, s1)
  diff.hs0.w(wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-spae(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ s0 = s1)
} = {
  exlimiiv(hs0, (∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ s0 = s1), s1 = hs0)
  pm2.61dan(s1 = hs0, (∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ s0 = s1), ∀(s0, s0 = hs0))
  a1d((s1 = hs0 ∧ ∀(s0, s0 = hs0)), ∀(s0, s0 = s1), s0 = s1)
  adantl(s1 = hs0, ∀(s0, s0 = hs0), s0 = s1)
  aeveq(s0, hs0, s0, s1)
  con4d((s1 = hs0 ∧ ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = hs0)), ∀(s0, s0 = s1), s0 = s1)
  impcom(s1 = hs0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = hs0), (¬ s0 = s1 → ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)))
  com13(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = hs0), s1 = hs0, ¬ s0 = s1, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  syl6(¬ s0 = s1, s1 = hs0, (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = hs0)→ ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)), ∀(s0, s1 = hs0))
  ax13v(s0, s1, hs0)
  con3d(∀(s0, s1 = hs0), ∀(s0, s0 = hs0), ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  al2imi(s0, s1 = hs0, s0 = s1, s0 = hs0)
  equtrr(s1, hs0, s0)
  ax6evr(hs0, s1)
  diff.hs0.w((∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ s0 = s1))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: wl-speqv
blocks.content: Under the assumption ` -. x = y ` a specialized version of ~ sp is provable from Tarski's FOL and ~ ax13v only. Note that this reverts the implication in ~ ax13lem1 , so in fact ` ( -. x = y -> ( A. x z = y <-> z = y ) ) ` holds. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 17-Apr-2021.)

blocks.name: wl-19.8eqv
blocks.content: Under the assumption ` -. x = y ` a specialized version of ~ 19.8a is provable from Tarski's FOL and ~ ax13v only. Note that this reverts the implication in ~ ax13lem2 , so in fact ` ( -. x = y -> ( E. x z = y <-> z = y ) ) ` holds. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 17-Apr-2021.)

blocks.name: wl-19.2reqv
blocks.content: Under the assumption ` -. x = y ` the reverse direction of ~ 19.2 is provable from Tarski's FOL and ~ ax13v only. Note that in conjunction with ~ 19.2 in fact ` ( -. x = y -> ( A. x z = y <-> E. x z = y ) ) ` holds. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 17-Apr-2021.)

blocks.name: wl-nfalv
blocks.content: If ` x ` is not present in ` ph ` , it is not free in ` A. y ph ` . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 11-Jan-2020.)

blocks.name: wl-nfimf1
blocks.content: An antecedent is irrelevant to a not-free property, if it always holds. I used this variant of ~ nfim in ~ dvelimdf to simplify the proof. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 14-Oct-2018.)

blocks.name: wl-nfnbi
blocks.content: Being free does not depend on an outside negation in an expression. This theorem is slightly more general than ~ nfn or ~ nfnd . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-May-2018.)

blocks.name: wl-nfae1
blocks.content: Unlike ~ nfae , this specialized theorem avoids ~ ax-11 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 26-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-nfnae1
blocks.content: Unlike ~ nfnae , this specialized theorem avoids ~ ax-11 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 27-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-aetr
blocks.content: A transitive law for variable identifying expressions. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 30-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-dral1d
blocks.content: A version of ~ dral1 with a context. Note: At first glance one might be tempted to generalize this (or a similar) theorem by weakening the first two hypotheses adding a ` x = y ` , ` A. x x = y ` or ` ph ` antecedent. ~ wl-equsal1i and ~ nf5di show that this is in fact pointless. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 28-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-dral1d(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wi(w0, wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wb(wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2))))
  -| wnf(s0, w0)
  -| wnf(s1, w0)
  -| wi(w0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w1, w2)))
} = {
  com12(w0, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wb(wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2)))
  pm5.74rd(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), w0, wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2))
  3bitr3g(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wi(w0, wal(s0, w1)), wi(w0, wal(s1, w2)), wal(s0, wi(w0, w1)), wal(s1, wi(w0, w2)))
  dral1(s0, s1, wi(w0, w1), wi(w0, w2))
  sps(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(wi(w0, w1), wi(w0, w2)))
  pm5.74d(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0, w1, w2)
  com12(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0, wb(w1, w2))
  19.21(s0, w0, w1)
  19.21(s1, w0, w2)
}

blocks.name: wl-cbvalnaed
blocks.content: ~ wl-cbvalnae with a context. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 28-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-cbvalnaed(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2)))
  -| wnf(s0, w0)
  -| wnf(s1, w0)
  -| wi(w0, wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s1, w1)))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s0, w2)))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w1, w2)))
} = {
  pm2.61dan(w0, wb(wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2)), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  imp(w0, wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wb(wal(s0, w1), wal(s1, w2)))
  wl-dral1d(s0, s1, w0, w1, w2)
  cbv2(s0, s1, wa(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), w1, w2)
  nfan(s0, w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  nfnae(s0, s0, s1)
  nfan(s1, w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  wl-nfnae1(s1, s0)
  imp(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s1, w1))
  imp(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s0, w2))
  adantr(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w1, w2)))
}

blocks.name: wl-cbvalnae
blocks.content: A more general version of ~ cbval when non-free properties depend on a distinctor. Such expressions arise in proofs aiming at the elimination of distinct variable constraints, specifically in application of ~ dvelimf , ~ nfsb2 or ~ dveeq1 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 4-Jun-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-cbvalnae(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wb(wal(s0, w0), wal(s1, w1))
  -| wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s1, w0))
  -| wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s0, w1))
  -| wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w0, w1))
} = {
  mptru(wb(wal(s0, w0), wal(s1, w1)))
  wl-cbvalnaed(s0, s1, wtru, w0, w1)
  nftru(s0)
  nftru(s1)
  a1i(wtru, wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s1, w0)))
  a1i(wtru, wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wnf(s0, w1)))
  a1i(wtru, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w0, w1)))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-cbvalnae(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0, w0)↔ ∀(s1, w1))
  ⊣ (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ F/(s1, w0))
  ⊣ (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ F/(s0, w1))
  ⊣ (s0 = s1 →(w0 ↔ w1))
} = {
  mptru((∀(s0, w0)↔ ∀(s1, w1)))
  wl-cbvalnaed(s0, s1, wtru, w0, w1)
  nftru(s0)
  nftru(s1)
  a1i(wtru, (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ F/(s1, w0)))
  a1i(wtru, (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ F/(s0, w1)))
  a1i(wtru, (s0 = s1 →(w0 ↔ w1)))
}

blocks.name: wl-nfs1t
blocks.content: If ` y ` is not free in ` ph ` , ` x ` is not free in ` [ y / x ] ph ` . Closed form of ~ nfs1 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 27-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-equsalvw
blocks.content: Version of ~ equsalv with a disjoint variable condition, and of ~ equsal with two disjoint variable conditions, which requires fewer axioms. See also the dual form ~ equsexvw . This theorem lays the foundation to a transformation of expressions called substitution of set variables in a wff. Only in this particular context we additionally assume ` ph ` and ` y ` disjoint, stated here as ` ph ( x ) ` . Similarly the disjointness of ` ps ` and ` x ` is expressed by ` ps ( y ) ` . Both ` ph ` and ` ps ` may still depend on other set variables, but that is irrelevant here. We want to transform ` ph ( x ) ` into ` ps ( y ) ` such that ` ps ` depends on ` y ` the same way as ` ph ` depends on ` x ` . This dependency is expressed in our hypothesis (called implicit substitution): ` ( x = y -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) ` . For primitive enough ` ph ` a sort of textual substitution of ` x ` by ` y ` is sufficient for such transformation. But note: ` ph ` must not contain wff variables, and the substitution is no proper textual substitution either. We still need grammar information to not accidently replace the x in a token 'x.' denoting multiplication, but only catch set variables ` x ` . Our current stage of development allows only equations and quantifiers make up such primitives. Thanks to ~ equequ1 and ~ cbvalvw we can then prove in a mechanical way that in fact the implicit substitution holds for each instance. If ` ph ` contains wff variables we cannot use textual transformation any longer, since we don't know how to replace ` y ` for ` x ` in placeholders of unknown structure. Our theorem now states, that the generic expression ` A. x ( x = y -> ph ) ` formally behaves as if such a substitution was possible and made. (Contributed by BJ, 31-May-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-equsald
blocks.content: Deduction version of ~ equsal . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 27-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-equsald(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w1)), w2))
  -| wnf(s0, w0)
  -| wi(w0, wnf(s0, w2))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w1, w2)))
} = {
  3bitr4d(w0, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w1)), w2, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w2)), wi(wex(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), w2))
  syl(w0, wb(wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w2)), wi(wex(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), w2)), wnf(s0, w2))
  19.23t(s0, w2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  albid(s0, w0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w1), wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w2))
  pm5.74d(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w1, w2)
  a1i(w0, wb(w2, wi(wex(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), w2)))
  a1bi(w2, wex(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  ax6e(s0, s1)
}

blocks.name: wl-equsal
blocks.content: A useful equivalence related to substitution. (Contributed by NM, 2-Jun-1993.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 12-Aug-2011.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 3-Oct-2016.) It seems proving ~ wl-equsald first, and then deriving more specialized versions ~ wl-equsal and ~ wl-equsal1t then is more efficient than the other way round, which is possible, too. See also ~ equsal . (Revised by Wolf Lammen, 27-Jul-2019.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)

blocks.name: wl-equsal1t
blocks.content: The expression ` x = y ` in antecedent position plays an important role in predicate logic, namely in implicit substitution. However, occasionally it is irrelevant, and can safely be dropped. A sufficient condition for this is when ` x ` (or ` y ` or both) is not free in ` ph ` . This theorem is more fundamental than ~ equsal , ~ spimt or ~ sbft , to which it is related. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 19-Aug-2018.)

blocks.name: wl-equsalcom
blocks.content: This simple equivalence eases substitution of one expression for the other. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 1-Sep-2018.)

blocks.name: wl-equsal1i
blocks.content: The antecedent ` x = y ` is irrelevant, if one or both setvar variables are not free in ` ph ` . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 1-Sep-2018.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-equsal1i(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {
  |- w0
  -| wo(wnf(s0, w0), wnf(s1, w0))
  -| wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)
} = {
  mp2(w0, wo(wnf(s0, w0), wnf(s1, w0)), wal(s0, wal(s1, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0))))
  gen2(s0, s1, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0))
  jaoi(wnf(s0, w0), wnf(s1, w0), wi(wal(s0, wal(s1, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0))), w0))
  syl5ib(wnf(s0, w0), wal(s0, wal(s1, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0))), w0, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)))
  alcoms(s0, s1, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0), wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)))
  sp(s1, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)))
  wl-equsal1t(s0, s1, w0)

  pm2.61d2(wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))))), wb(wsb(s2, s1, wal(s0, w0)), wal(s0, wsb(s2, s1, w0))), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2))))

  bitr4d(wa(wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2))))), wsb(s2, s1, wal(s0, w0)), wal(s0, wsb(s2, s1, w0)), wal(s1, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0))))
  sylan9bbr(wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wsb(s2, s1, wal(s0, w0)), wal(s1, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0))), wal(s1, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), wal(s0, w0))))
  sb4b(s1, s2, wal(s0, w0))
  albid(s1, wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))))), wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), wal(s0, w0)), wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))

  nfeqf(s0, s1, s2)

  19.21t(s0, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)
  adantl(wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wb(wal(s0, wsb(s2, s1, w0)), wal(s1, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))))

  albid(s0, wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wsb(s2, s1, w0), wal(s1, wi(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))

blocks.name: wl-ich
blocks.content: Infer one criterium for interchangeability from another. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Aug-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-ich(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, wff w0) {
  |- wi(wal(s0, wal(s1, wb(wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)), wsb(s1, s2, wsb(s0, s3, w0))))), wb(w0, wsb(s2, s4, wsb(s3, s2, wsb(s4, s3, w0)))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
  -| diffsw(s1, w0)
  -| diffsw(s4, w0)
} = {
  3bitr3g(wal(s0, wal(s1, wb(wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)), wsb(s1, s2, wsb(s0, s3, w0))))), w0, wsb(s2, s4, wsb(s3, s2, wsb(s4, s3, w0))), wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)))), wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, wsb(s1, s2, wsb(s0, s3, w0)))))
  wl-2spsbbi(s0, s1, s3, s2, wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)), wsb(s1, s2, wsb(s0, s3, w0)))
  bitri(wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)))), w0, wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s1, s3, w0)))
  sbbii(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0))), wsb(s1, s3, w0))
  sbid2vw(s2, s0, wsb(s1, s3, w0))
  sbid2vw(s3, s1, w0)
  sbco4(s3, s1, s2, s0, s4, w0)
  diffss.ex(s2, s0)
  diff.wsb.s(s0, s1, s3, w0)
  diffss.ex(s3, s1)
  diffss.ex(s3, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
}

blocks.name: wl-ich-lem1
blocks.content: Lemma. Simplify substitution expression when two particular variables are the same. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 5-Aug-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-ich-lem1a
blocks.content: Lemma. A substitution of a non-free variable has no effect. Give the distinctor in a form that can be easily eliminiated. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 6-Aug-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-ich-lem1b
blocks.content: Lemma. When substituting successively for two always equal variables, the second substitution has no effect. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 6-Aug-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-ich-lem1ab
blocks.content: Lemma. A substitution of a non-free variable has no effect. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 6-Aug-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-ich-lem1c
blocks.content: Lemma. If in an interchangeability context ` x ` is not free in ` ph ` , the same holds for ` y ` . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 6-Aug-2023.)

  nfal(s1, s3, wb(wsb(s2, s1, wsb(s3, s0, w0)), wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, w0))))
  nfbi(s1, wsb(s2, s1, wsb(s3, s0, w0)), wsb(s3, s1, wsb(s2, s0, w0)))

thm wl-ich-lem4(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, wff w0) {

thm wl-ich-lem6(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, wff w0) {

  expcom(wal(s0, wal(s1, wb(wsb(s0, s2, wsb(s1, s3, w0)), wsb(s1, s2, wsb(s0, s3, w0))))), wal(s2, wnf(s3, w0)), wal(s3, wnf(s2, w0)))

thm wl-lem-moexsb(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {

} = {
  impbid1(wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wex(s0, w0), wsb(s1, s0, w0))
  exlimd(s0, wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), w0, wsb(s1, s0, w0))
  nfa1(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  nfs1v(s0, s1, w0)
  syl6ibr(wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), w0, wsb(s1, s0, w0), wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)))
  syli(wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), w0, wal(s0, wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), w0)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  sp(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  ax12v2(s0, s1, w0)
  sb6(s1, s0, w0)
  spsbe(s1, s0, w0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
}

thm wl-mo2df(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {

  -| wi(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  -| wi(w0, wnf(s1, w1))
} = {
  syl5bb(w0, wmo(s0, w1), wex(s1, wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))))
  df-mo(s0, hs0, w1)
  cbvexd(hs0, s1, w0, wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  nfald(s1, s0, w0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  nfimd(s1, w0, w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))
  syl(w0, wnf(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  naecoms(s0, s1, wnf(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  nfeqf1(s1, s0, hs0)
  ex(w0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))))
  sylan(w0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  albid(s0, wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1))), wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  nfan1(s0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)))
  nfnae(s0, s0, s1)
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  adantl(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  imbi2d(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  equequ2(hs0, s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(w1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.w(wal(s0, wi(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-mo2df(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(∃*(s0, w1)↔ ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1)))))
  ⊣ F/(s0, w0)
  ⊣ F/(s1, w0)
  ⊣ (w0 → ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  ⊣ (w0 → F/(s1, w1))
} = {
  syl5bb(w0, ∃*(s0, w1), ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1))), ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = hs0))))
  df-mo(s0, hs0, w1)
  cbvexd(hs0, s1, w0, ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = hs0)), ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1)))
  nfald(s1, s0, w0, (w1 → s0 = hs0))
  nfimd(s1, w0, w1, s0 = hs0)
  syl(w0, F/(s1, s0 = hs0), ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  naecoms(s0, s1, F/(s1, s0 = hs0))
  nfeqf1(s1, s0, hs0)
  ex(w0, hs0 = s1, (∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = hs0))↔ ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1))))
  sylan(w0, hs0 = s1, (∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = hs0))↔ ∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1))), ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  albid(s0, (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)∧ hs0 = s1), (w1 → s0 = hs0), (w1 → s0 = s1))
  nfan1(s0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1)
  nfnae(s0, s0, s1)
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  adantl(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1, ((w1 → s0 = hs0)↔(w1 → s0 = s1)))
  imbi2d(hs0 = s1, w1, s0 = hs0, s0 = s1)
  equequ2(hs0, s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(w1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.w(∀(s0,(w1 → s0 = s1)))
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}

thm wl-eudf(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(weu(s0, w1), wex(s1, wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))))
  -| wnf(s0, w0)
  -| wnf(s1, w0)
  -| wi(w0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  -| wi(w0, wnf(s1, w1))
} = {
  syl5bb(w0, weu(s0, w1), wex(s1, wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))))
  eu6(s0, hs0, w1)
  cbvexd(hs0, s1, w0, wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  nfald(s1, s0, w0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  nfbid(s1, w0, w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))
  syl(w0, wnf(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  naecoms(s0, s1, wnf(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  nfeqf1(s1, s0, hs0)
  ex(w0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))))
  sylan(w0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  albid(s0, wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1))), wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  nfan1(s0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)))
  nfnae(s0, s0, s1)
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  adantl(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  bibi2d(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  equequ2(hs0, s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(w1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.w(wal(s0, wb(w1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}

thm wl-eudf(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(∃!(s0, w1)↔ ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(w1 ↔ s0 = s1)))))

  ex(w0, hs0 = s1, (∀(s0,(w1 ↔ s0 = hs0))↔ ∀(s0,(w1 ↔ s0 = s1))))

  albid(s0, (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)∧ hs0 = s1), (w1 ↔ s0 = hs0), (w1 ↔ s0 = s1))
  nfan1(s0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1)
  nfnae(s0, s0, s1)
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  adantl(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1, ((w1 ↔ s0 = hs0)↔(w1 ↔ s0 = s1)))

blocks.name: wl-euequf
blocks.content: ~ euequ proved with a distinctor. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 23-Sep-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-euequf(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  |- wi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), weu(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
} = {
  sylibr(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), weu(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))))
  mpi(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))), wex(hs0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1))))
  ax6ev(hs0, s1)
  eximd(hs0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wal(s0, wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))))
  nfv(hs0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  alrimdd(s0, wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  nfna1(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  a1i(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wi(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))))
  equcoms(hs0, s1, wb(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))
  equequ2(s1, hs0, s0)
  eu6(s0, hs0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.w(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
}

thm wl-euequf(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  ⊢ (¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1)→ ∃!(s0, s0 = s1))
} = {
  sylibr(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), ∃!(s0, s0 = s1), ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0))))
  mpi(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0))), ∃(hs0, hs0 = s1))
  ax6ev(hs0, s1)
  eximd(hs0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1, ∀(s0,(s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0)))
  nfv(hs0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  alrimdd(s0, ¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), hs0 = s1, (s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0))
  nfna1(s0, s0 = s1)
  nfeqf2(s0, s1, hs0)
  a1i(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1), (hs0 = s1 →(s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0)))
  equcoms(hs0, s1, (s0 = s1 ↔ s0 = hs0))
  equequ2(s1, hs0, s0)
  eu6(s0, hs0, s0 = s1)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.w(¬ ∀(s0, s0 = s1))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(s0 = s1)
}

thm wl-mo2t(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {

} = {
  syl5bb(wal(s0, wnf(s1, w0)), wmo(s0, w0), wex(s1, wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))), wex(hs0, wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))))))

  a1i(wal(s0, wnf(s1, w0)), wi(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wb(wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0)))), wal(s0, wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))))
  albidv(s0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s1)), wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(hs0))), wi(w0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))

thm wl-mo2t(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0, F/(s1, w0))→(∃*(s0, w0)↔ ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(w0 → s0 = s1)))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
} = {
  syl5bb(∀(s0, F/(s1, w0)), ∃*(s0, w0), ∃(s1, ∀(s0,(w0 → s0 = s1))), ∃(hs0, ∀(s0,(w0 → s0 = hs0))))
  df-mo(s0, hs0, w0)
  cbvexd(hs0, s1, ∀(s0, F/(s1, w0)), ∀(s0,(w0 → s0 = hs0)), ∀(s0,(w0 → s0 = s1)))
  nfal(s1, s0, F/(s1, w0))
  nfnf1(s1, w0)
  nfald(s1, s0, ∀(s0, F/(s1, w0)), (w0 → s0 = hs0))
  nfa1(s0, F/(s1, w0))
  nfimd(s1, ∀(s0, F/(s1, w0)), w0, s0 = hs0)

blocks.name: wl-sb8mot
blocks.content: Substitution of variable in universal quantifier. Closed form of ~ sb8mo . This theorem relates to ~ wl-mo3t , since replacing ` ph ` with ` [ y / x ] ph ` in the latter yields subexpressions like ` [ x / y ] [ y / x ] ph ` , which can be reduced to ` ph ` via ~ sbft and ~ sbco . So ` E* x ph <-> E* y [ y / x ] ph ` is provable from ~ wl-mo3t in a simple fashion, unfortunately only if ` x ` and ` y ` are known to be distinct. To avoid any hassle with distinctors, we prefer to derive this theorem independently, ignoring the close connection between both theorems. From an educational standpoint, one would assume ~ wl-mo3t to be more fundamental, as it hints how the "at most one" objects on both sides of the biconditional correlate (they are the same), if they exist at all, and then prove this theorem from it. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 11-Aug-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-axc11rc11
blocks.content: Proving ~ axc11r from ~ axc11 . The hypotheses are two instances of ~ axc11 used in the proof here. Some systems introduce ~ axc11 as an axiom, see for example System S2 in https://us.metamath.org/downloads/finiteaxiom.pdf . By contrast, this database sees the variant ~ axc11r , directly derived from ~ ax-12 , as foundational. Later ~ axc11 is proven somewhat trickily, requiring ~ ax-10 and ~ ax-13 , see its proof. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 18-Jul-2023.)

blocks.name: ax-wl-11v
blocks.content: Version of ~ ax-11 with distinct variable conditions. Currently implemented as an axiom to detect unintended references to the foundational axiom ~ ax-11 . It will later be converted into a theorem directly based on ~ ax-11 . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 28-Jun-2019.)

  sylan2(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1)))), wb(wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))
  con3i(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1))), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2))))
  axc11n(s1, s2)
  imp(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wb(wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0))))
  sylibr(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wi(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wb(wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0)))), wb(wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0)))))
  bitr3d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0))), wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))))
  anbi1d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))
  3bitr3g(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0))), wal(s0, wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))), wal(s1, wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, w0))))
  dral1(s0, s1, wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, w0)))
  bitr4d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wa(wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, w0)), wa(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))))
  anbi1d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))
  notbid(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s2))), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2))))
  wl-ax11-lem1(s0, s1, s2)
  pm5.32d(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s2, w0), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  syl5(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wb(wal(s2, w0), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1)))))
  con3i(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
  axc11n(s2, s1)
  ex(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1)))), wb(wal(s2, w0), wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))))
  albid(s2, wa(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1))))), w0, wsb(s0, s1, w0))
  wl-ax11-lem4(s2, s0, s1)
  adantr(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1)))), wb(w0, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  sps(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wb(w0, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  equcoms(s0, s1, wb(w0, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  sbequ12(s1, s0, w0)
  wl-ax11-lem7(s0, s2, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  wl-ax11-lem7(s1, s2, wal(s2, w0))
  pm5.32(wn(wal(s1, wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wal(s1, wal(s2, w0)))
  diffss.ex(s2, s0)
}

blocks.name: wl-ax11-lem9
blocks.content: The easy part when ` x ` coincides with ` y ` . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 30-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-ax11-lem10
blocks.content: We now have prepared everything. The unwanted variable ` u ` is just in one place left. ~ pm2.61 can be used in conjunction with ~ wl-ax11-lem9 to eliminate the second antecedent. Missing is something along the lines of ~ ax-6 , so we could remove the first antecedent. But the Metamath axioms cannot accomplish this. Such a rule must reside one abstraction level higher than all others: It says that a distinctor implies a distinct variable condition on its contained setvar. This is only needed if such conditions are required, as ax-11v does. The result of this study is for me, that you cannot introduce a setvar capturing this condition, and hope to eliminate it later. (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 30-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: wl-clabv
blocks.content: Variant of ~ df-clab , where the element ` x ` is required to be disjoint from the class it is taken from. This restriction meets similar ones found in other definitions and axioms like ~ ax-ext , ~ df-clel and ~ df-cleq . ` x e. A ` with ` A ` depending on ` x ` can be the source of side effects, that you rather want to be aware of. So here we eliminate one possible way of letting this slip in instead. An expression ` x e. A ` with ` x ` , ` A ` not disjoint, is now only introduced either via ~ ax-8 , ~ ax-9 , or ~ df-clel . Theorem ~ cleljust shows that a possible choice does not matter. The original ~ df-clab can be rederived, see ~ wl-dfclab . In an implementation this theorem is the only user of df-clab. (Contributed by NM, 26-May-1993.) Element and class are disjoint. (Revised by Wolf Lammen, 31-May-2023.)

blocks.name: wl-dfclab
blocks.content: Rederive ~ df-clab from ~ wl-clabv . (Contributed by Wolf Lammen, 31-May-2023.)
blocks.origin:
thm wl-dfclab(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {
  |- wb(wcel(cv(s0), cab(s1, w0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0))
} = {
  3bitri(wcel(cv(s0), cab(s1, w0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(hs0, wa(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s1, w0)))), wex(hs0, wa(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0))))
  df-clel(hs0, cv(s0), cab(s1, w0))
  exbii(hs0, wa(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s1, w0))), wa(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  pm5.32i(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s1, w0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0))
  syl5bb(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s1, w0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0), wsb(hs0, s1, w0))
  wl-clabv(hs0, s1, w0)
  sbequ(hs0, s0, s1, w0)
  bitr4i(wex(hs0, wa(wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0))), wsb(s0, s1, w0), wa(wex(hs0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0))), wsb(s0, s1, w0)))
  19.41v(hs0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), wsb(s0, s1, w0))
  biantrur(wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(hs0, wceq(cv(hs0), cv(s0))))
  ax6ev(hs0, s0)
  diff.hs0.c(cv(s0))
  diff.hs0.c(cab(s1, w0))
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.w(wsb(s0, s1, w0))
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-dfclab(setvar s0, setvar s1, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (s0 ∈ { s1 | w0 } ↔[s0 / s1]w0)
} = {
  3bitri(s0 ∈ { s1 | w0 }, [s0 / s1]w0, ∃(hs0,(hs0 = s0 ∧ hs0 ∈ { s1 | w0 })), ∃(hs0,(hs0 = s0 ∧[s0 / s1]w0)))
  df-clel(hs0, s0, { s1 | w0 })
  exbii(hs0, (hs0 = s0 ∧ hs0 ∈ { s1 | w0 }), (hs0 = s0 ∧[s0 / s1]w0))
  pm5.32i(hs0 = s0, hs0 ∈ { s1 | w0 }, [s0 / s1]w0)
  syl5bb(hs0 = s0, hs0 ∈ { s1 | w0 }, [s0 / s1]w0, [hs0 / s1]w0)
  wl-clabv(hs0, s1, w0)
  sbequ(hs0, s0, s1, w0)
  bitr4i(∃(hs0,(hs0 = s0 ∧[s0 / s1]w0)), [s0 / s1]w0, (∃(hs0, hs0 = s0)∧[s0 / s1]w0))
  19.41v(hs0, hs0 = s0, [s0 / s1]w0)
  biantrur([s0 / s1]w0, ∃(hs0, hs0 = s0))
  ax6ev(hs0, s0)
  diff.hs0.c(s0)
  diff.hs0.c({ s1 | w0 })
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.w([s0 / s1]w0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
}

thm wl-clabtv(setvar s0, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(cab(s0, w1), cab(s0, wi(w0, w1))))
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
} = {
  eqrdv(hs0, cab(s0, w1), cab(s0, wi(w0, w1)), w0)
  3bitr4g(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s0, w1)), wcel(cv(hs0), cab(s0, wi(w0, w1))), wsb(hs0, s0, w1), wsb(hs0, s0, wi(w0, w1)))
  sbbidv(hs0, s0, w0, w1, wi(w0, w1))
  biimt(w0, w1)
  df-clab(hs0, s0, w1)
  df-clab(hs0, s0, wi(w0, w1))
  diff.hs0.c(cab(s0, w1))
  diff.hs0.c(cab(s0, wi(w0, w1)))
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm wl-clabtv(setvar s0, wff w0, wff w1) {
  ⊢ (w0 → { s0 | w1 } = { s0 |(w0 → w1)})
  ⊣ d(s0, w0)
} = {
  eqrdv(hs0, { s0 | w1 }, { s0 |(w0 → w1)}, w0)
  3bitr4g(w0, hs0 ∈ { s0 | w1 }, hs0 ∈ { s0 |(w0 → w1)}, [hs0 / s0]w1, [hs0 / s0](w0 → w1))
  sbbidv(hs0, s0, w0, w1, (w0 → w1))
  biimt(w0, w1)
  df-clab(hs0, s0, w1)
  df-clab(hs0, s0, (w0 → w1))
  diff.hs0.c({ s0 | w1 })
  diff.hs0.c({ s0 |(w0 → w1)})
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
}
